TSC (technical)Technical Standards CatalogueDFE
TSC (training)Training Standards CouncilThe Training Standards Council (TSC) was the regulator for employment training standards and practice. It was a private limited company, based in Oxford, incorporated on 29 August 1997 and dissolved on 5 April 2004. The government's plans to reform post-16 education and training outside universities in England, outlined in the White Paper Learning to Succeed, demonstrated its commitment to work-based training and led to the provision of post-16 learning being merged under a new national body, the Learning and Skills Council. The LSC would be an independent inspectorate to assess the quality of provision for adult learning and work-based training and would build on the work undertaken by the Training Standards Council. Source Companies House BBC News Archive ViaSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-17DFE
TSHTeaching school hubsOver one thousand schools are set to receive expert support from some of the countrys highest performing schools as the Department for Education announces six new Teaching School Hubs today (7 January [2020]). Schools will benefit from a three-year programme of support, with each of the six successful schools acting as a regional hub and will receive funding to support between 200 to 300 other schools in the local area. This will give struggling schools direct access to the expertise from school leaders with a track record of improving challenging schools. Support could include delivering tailored professional development for teachers, hosting observations and visits or deploying system leaders to offer advice and guidance to local schools. This forms part of a new scheme, launched by the department last year, to simplify and strengthen how the government drives up school standards, building on the successes of the Teaching Schools and National Leaders of Education programmes. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentews/struggling-schools-set-for-specialist-support} accessed 2020-04-07DFE
TSITechnology Schools InitiativeSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-17DFE
TSIATransatlantic School Innovation AllianceTransatlantic School Innovation Alliance (TSIA) is a partnership designed to improve teaching and learning, and urban leadership through the creation of a network of schools in the UK and US. The goal is to blend the ideas and strategies from educators in the two countries with relevant research, and to design study and disseminate better ways of working. TSIA was piloted in 2006-07 and started fully in 2007-08 in and involves eight (rising to 12) schools from London. The partnership extended to the Black Country in the 2009-10 academic year and involves five schools with eight schools by summer 2010. Greater Manchester Challenge schools will join in January 2010 with 10 schools. The partnership closely mirrors many of the aims of City Challenge to raise standards and aspirations in these urban schools. There has been positive feedback from London schools that it is helping raise literacy levels by identifying, adapting and implementing successful ideas. The aims of the TSIA are: to focus on innovation; schools to drive their own development; to maximise the freedoms on schools and minimise bureaucracy; To identify and disseminate knowledge and skills. Links/Further Information Press Notice 19 November 2009: Black Country Challenge Children make transatlantic connection from American Embassy Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16DFE

TUSTrade Union Side
TVEITechnical and Vocational Education InitiativeAn initiative set up in 1983 aimed at supporting school and college provision of technical and pre-vocational courses for 14-18 year olds. Funded by the Department of Employment. Funding withdrawn from 1991 onwards leading to the end of the scheme. Source: Oxford Dictionary of Education 2008 Further information below from The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16 The Technical and Vocational Education Initiative (TVEI) which began as a national programme in 1987 and continued until 1997-98 helped equip young people with the knowledge and skills to succeed in adult and working life. It sought to relate the whole curriculum to the world of work, to promote work experience, to involve employers in school life and to help teachers gain and understanding of industry and commerce. It was managed by Government Offices (GOs) through contracts with Training and Enterprise Councils (TECs), Local Education Authority/local education authorities (LEAs) and others. TVEI funds (over 900m in total) supported targeted projects aimed at raising young people's levels of attainment. TVEI was extensively evaluated. The evidence showed that young people's career planning skills had been improved, that the programme had encouraged them to continue their learning post-16, and that personal, interpersonal and initiative skills had been enhanced.DFE
TVETTechnical and Vocational Education and TrainingDFE
TWESTraining and Work Experience SchemeDFE
TWIST (departmental organisational unit)Teacher Workload and Impact on Schools TeamYear(s) active (where known): 2019DFE
TYWDFTransforming Youth Work Development FundTransforming Youth Work Development Fund (TYWDF) was launched in 2002 with the intention of providing Local Authority youth services with additional funding to enhance the quality and capacity of youth work. This Fund has since become the Transforming Youth Work Performance Improvement Fund (TYWPIF). Aims of the fund 10 million was pledged by Ministers for each of 2003-04, 2004-05 and 2005-06 for the youth work programme. The key aims of the TYWDF were to: Support the implementation of Youth Service Plans Build capacity within the voluntary sector Introduce innovative and imaginative projects - particularly around cultural diversity, the promotion of Community Cohesion and the reduction of youth crime and anti-social behaviour Continue to bring youth services into closer engagement with Connexions The TYWPIF carries forward the previous agenda but also asks for youth services to focus resources on work around achieving performance measures. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16DFE
TYWPIFTransforming Youth Work Performance Improvement FundThe Transforming Youth Work Performance Improvement Fund (TYWPIF) is the successor to the Transforming Youth Work Development Fund (TYWDF). It was managed by Government Offices on behalf of the Department. The TYWPIF carries forward the TYWDF agenda but also asks for youth services to focus resources on work around achieving performance measures. Priorities for the fund are: To support youth services in the planning and managing of performance indicators Help in the implementation of the Youth Service Quality Mark *Help youth services with workforce development issues Bring about regional development and inter-authority collaboration Support innovative youth work, particularly sustainable development Support youth services make provision for activities in accordance with the Special Education Needs Disability Act Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-16DFE
u-projectActivities for Young People ProgrammeThe Activities for Young People Programme for 16-year-olds, also known as the u-project, was aimed at young people in England who were coming to the end of compulsory education (at the end of school year 11), with no real idea of what they wanted to do next. Those young people were more likely than others of drifting out of learning and into long-term disaffection. The aim of the u-project was to aid the transition from secondary school to adult life, by providing a structured programme of challenging activity and high-quality advice and guidance to encourage participants to remain in education or to take up training or employment. Activities on the programme were designed to offer the young people personal challenges, an opportunity to reflect, and a sense of achievement. Funding from the Big Lottery Fund ended in December 2004. DFE

UCETUniversities Council for the Education of TeachersThe Universities Council for the Education of Teachers acts as a national forum for the discussion of matters relating to the education of teachers and professional educators, and to the study of education in the university sector and contributes to the formulation of policy in these fields. Its members are UK universities involved in teacher education, and a number of colleges of higher education in the university sector. Source: {UCET|http://www.ucet.ac.uk/} accessed 2016-07-20DFE

UCLESUniversity of Cambridge Local Examinations SyndicateCambridge Assessment was established as the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES) by the University of Cambridge in 1858. We were set up to administer local examinations for students who were not members of the University of Cambridge, with the aim of raising standards in education. We also inspected schools. Today, we develop and deliver examinations and tests in 170 countries. Source: {Cambridge Assessment|http://www.cambridgeassessment.org.uk/about-us/who-we-are/our-heritage/} accessed 2019-03-18DFE
UCLSUniversal Credit Live ServiceDWP
UCUUniversity and College UnionThe AUT joined with NATFHE to form the University and College Union (UCU) on 1 June 2006.DFE
UFCUniversities Funding CouncilSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18DFE
UfIUniversity for IndustryUfi was created in 1998 as the University for Industry and is a Department for Business, Innovation and Skills-supported organisation, although it is not an NDPB. Ufi is the organisation responsible for the operation of Learndirect across England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and UK online centres in England. Remit Ufis remit is: to be a technologically innovative and entrepreneurial force in the improvement of skills for work to focus on the lower skilled and smaller businesses in a way which complements the rest of the education and skills sector to provide other public services including advice and access to online public services through UK online centres However, Ufi contributes beyond the worlds of adult learning and workforce development, working across government departments on government e-services, digital inclusion, prison reform, financial literacy, citizenship and community regeneration. Learndirect Ufi launched Learndirect in October 2000. Since its launch, nearly 2 million learners have taken Learndirect courses in subjects ranging from the Skills for Life of literacy and numeracy to languages, management, English for Speakers of Other Languages and IT at all levels. Supported by staff in centres, or at home or work by online tutors, Learndirect learners can choose to work towards nationally recognised qualifications including the Certificates in Adult Literacy and Numeracy, CLAIT and the ECDL (European Computer Driving Licence). Additionally, the Learndirect advice service has provided free, impartial careers guidance and advice on over a million learning opportunities to more than seven million callers, and more than 17 million information and advice sessions through its website. UK online centres In 2003, Ufi took on responsibility for UK online centres from the Department for Education and Skills. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-02-05DFE
UGCUniversity Grants CommitteeThe University Grants Committee was an advisory committee of the British government, which advised on the distribution of grant funding amongst the British universities. It was in existence from 1919 until 1989. Its functions have now largely been taken over by the higher education funding councils. Source: {Wikipedia|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Grants_Committee_(United_Kingdom)} accessed 2019-06-17DFE
UIUser InterfaceDFE
UIFSMUniversal Infant Free School MealsThe Children and Families Act 2014 places a legal duty on all state-funded schools in England, including academies and free schools to offer a free school lunch to all pupils in reception, year 1 and year 2 from September 2014. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/universal-infant-free-school-meals-guide-for-schools-and-local-authorities} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
UKUnited KingdomDFE
UK NARICNational Academic Recognition CentreUK NARIC was the UK's National Agency responsible for providing information and opinion on academic, vocational and professional qualifications from across the world. As the National Agency, managed on behalf of the UK Government, UK NARIC provide the only official source of information on international education and training systems and qualifications and skills attained outside the UK. UK ENIC is the UK National Information Centre for the recognition and evaluation of international qualifications and skills. Following the UK's departure from the European Union, the UK NARIC recognition agency function has to change from a NARIC (which is an EU-only title) to an ENIC (the wider European title for national recognition agencies) in order to meet the UK's continuing treaty obligations under the Lisbon Recognition Convention. Therefore, on 1 March 2021, the UK NARIC agency title becomes UK ENIC, operated and managed by Ecctis Limited. Source accessed 2021-04-19DFE
UKAISUK Academy for Information SystemsSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18DFE
UKCCISUK Council for Child Internet SafetyThe UK Council for Internet Safety (UKCIS) is the successor to the UK Council for Child Internet Safety (UKCCIS), with an expanded scope to improve online safety for everyone in the UK. The Executive Board brings together expertise from a range of organisations in the tech industry, civil society and public sector. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentews/board-announced-for-new-uk-council-for-internet-safety} accessed 2019-02-18 The proposal to expand the remit of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety was outlined in the Government's Internet Safety Strategy Green Paper in October 2017. The new Council will have specific objectives reflecting children and young peoples special needs for care and protection, and will build on the pioneering work of UKCCIS in this area. The Executive Board will contain representatives of childrens organisations. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentewsew-council-for-internet-safety-in-the-uk} accessed 2019-02-18 UKCCIS is a group of more than 200 organisations drawn from across government, industry, law, academia and charity sectors that work in partnership to help keep children safe online. The Council was established in 2010 following a review by Professor Tanya Byron and discusses and takes action on topical issues concerning childrens use of the internet. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/groups/uk-council-for-child-internet-safety-ukccis} accessed 2015-06-11 The UK Council for Child Internet Safety (UKCCIS) was formed in September 2008. The establishment of a UK Council for Child Internet Safety was a key recommendation in Professor Tanya Byrons Report. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18DFE
UKCESUK Commission for Employment and SkillsUKCES are a publicly funded, industry-led organisation that offers guidance on skills and employment issues in the UK. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/uk-commission-for-employment-and-skills/about} accessed 2015-05-28 UKCES came into operation on 1 April 2008. It replaced the Sector Skills Development Agency (SSDA) and National Employment Panel, although with a different remit and responsibilities. UKCES also took over the running of the Skills for Business Network from SSDA. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18DFE
UKCGEUK Council for Graduate EducationSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-18DFE
UKCISUK Council for Internet SafetyThe UK Council for Internet Safety (UKCIS) is the successor to the UK Council for Child Internet Safety (UKCCIS), with an expanded scope to improve online safety for everyone in the UK. The Executive Board brings together expertise from a range of organisations in the tech industry, civil society and public sector. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentews/board-announced-for-new-uk-council-for-internet-safety} accessed 2019-02-18 The proposal to expand the remit of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety was outlined in the Government's Internet Safety Strategy Green Paper in October 2017. The new Council will have specific objectives reflecting children and young peoples special needs for care and protection, and will build on the pioneering work of UKCCIS in this area. The Executive Board will contain representatives of childrens organisations. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/governmentewsew-council-for-internet-safety-in-the-uk} accessed 2019-02-18DFE
UKCISAUK Council for International Student AffairsThe UK Council for International Student Affairs is the UK's national advisory body serving the interests of international students and those who work with them. Formerly called UKCOSA. Source: {UKCISA website|http://www.ukcisa.org.uk/International-Students/About-UKCISA/#} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
UKCOSAUK Council for Overseas Student AffairsThe UK Council for International Education, provided guidance and support to students, especially international students. It was an independent, not-for-profit organisation and received funding from the DfES (2001-2007). Renamed UKCISA in 2007. UK Council for Overseas Student Affairs Source: The Knowledge 2019-03-18DFE

ULNUnique Learner NumbersA ULN is a 10-digit reference number which is used alongside and to access the Personal Learning Record of anyone over the age of 14 involved in UK education or training. UNIYYUnited Nations International Year of YouthOn 18 December 2009, the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution A/RES/64/134 proclaiming the year commencing on 12 August 2010 as the International Year of Youth: Dialogue and Mutual Understanding. The Year will coincide with the 25th anniversary of the first International Youth Year in 1985 on the theme Participation, Development and Peace. The resolution A/RES/64/134: https://undocs.org/A/RES/64/134 Source: {UN|https://social.un.org/youthyear/} accessed 2019-06-14DFE

UPNUnique pupil numbersFirst introduced during the 1999/2000 academic year. The unique pupil number (UPN) is a 13-character code that identifies each pupil in the maintained school system. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/unique-pupil-numbers} accessed 2015-06-11DFE

USSUniversities Superannuation SchemeDFE
UTCUniversity technical collegesUniversity technical colleges (UTCs) are all-ability and mixed gender state funded schools, independent of local authorities. They are not extensions of or conversions from existing provision, but new 14 to 19 academies, typically with 500-800 pupils. UTCs specialise in subjects that need modern, technical, industry-standard equipment, such as engineering and construction, and teach these disciplines alongside business skills and a broad, general education. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/university-technical-colleges-from-2014-how-to-apply} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
UTTUCAS Teacher TrainingUTT is a single admissions system for postgraduate teacher training, covering Higher Education, SCITT, School Direct and School Direct (salaried) programmes. Source: {UCAS|https://www.ucas.com/corporateews-and-key-documentsews/ucas-teacher-training-first-monthly-statistics-published} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
UUKUniversities UKUniversities UK is the voice of universities, helping to maintain the world-leading strength of the UK university sector and supporting our members to achieve their aims and objectives. Source: {UUK website|https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/about/Pages/about-us.aspx} accessed 2019-12-24DFE
UUKiUniversities UK InternationalUUKi is the international arm of Universities UK, representing UK universities and acting in their collective interests globally. [They] actively promote universities abroad, provide trusted information for and about them, and create new opportunities for the sector. Source: {UUKi website|https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/International} accessed 2019-12-24DFE

VAVoluntary AidedSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VA/DTValue-Added/Distance TravelledThe Learner Achievement Tracker (LAT) was a piece of software for tracking learner progress that the LSC made available to all its providers. Part of the measures of success initiative, the LAT was intended to help providers measure qualification success rate (QSR), recognising and recording progress and achievement (RARPA) and value-added/distance travelled (VA/DT). Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-04-17DFE
VASVoluntary aided schoolsVoluntary-aided (VA) schools are maintained schools and often, but not always, have a religious character. These schools are eligible for capital funding by grant from the department. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/voluntary-aided-schools-capital-funding} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
VASISVoluntary-aided schools information systemThe voluntary-aided schools information system (VASIS) is a password-controlled site for VA schools, LAs and dioceses to access information about projects, claims and allocations. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/guidance/voluntary-aided-schools-capital-funding} accessed 2018-06-13DFE
VATValue Added TaxCivil Service WideTax / Finance
VBSVetting and Barring SchemeThe Vetting and Barring Scheme (VBS) went live on 12 October 2009. The scheme is delivered by the Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) and the Independent Safeguarding Authority (ISA) under the Safeguarding and Vulnerable Groups Act 2006. VBS covers England, Wales and Northern Ireland; a separate but aligned scheme was implemented in Scotland in 2010.DFE
VCVoluntary ControlledSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VCVideo ConferenceCivil Service Wide
VCEVocational Certificate of EducationThe Vocational Certificate of Education (VCE) was introduced in September 2000 to replace the advanced General National Vocational Qualification. Following a review, VCEs were renamed GCEs (General Certificates of Education) in applied subjects or A Levels in applied subjects. The revised qualifications, which were introduced in September 2005, provide a broad introduction to vocational areas and encourage teaching and assessment approaches in work-related contexts. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VCSVoluntary and Community SectorThe Voluntary and Community Sector (VCS) is an umbrella term that covers a very diverse range of providers who are working with a specific voluntary or community aim. The sector is large and varied. It is made up of charities and voluntary groups as well as informal community-based organisations. Members of the sector can vary from international, well-known companies with thousands of paid staff, to small community groups with no paid staff. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VCTVoluntary Competitive TenderingSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VDUDisplay screen equipmentDFE
VEAZVirtual Education Action ZonesVirtual Education Action Zones (VEAZ) were introduced by the Department for Education and Employment in 1999. They were an innovative build-on to Education Action Zones and were designed to explore the improvements that could be achieved using information technology - with the schools set to be connected by video-conferencing and e-mail. Each of the participating schools had video-conferencing equipment installed, with access to e-mail improved for pupils and the 1,000 teachers and support staff. The schools, including both primary and secondary, were set up links in groups of three - with the groups constantly changing until all the schools have worked with each other. Source: {BBC|http:/ews.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/506381.stm} accessed 2019-03-04 and The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VETVocational Education and TrainingDFE
VIVisually ImpairedSource: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VICVirtual Information Centre
VLEVirtual Learning EnvironmentA Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) is an ICT-based environment that supports the delivery of online learning. VLEs allow controlled access to pieces of information, which can be individually assessed and recorded. VLEs also allow the tracking of student activity and progress, support of online learning, and electronic communication between the learner, tutor and others. The teacher and student have two different access levels: the teacher can see what the student sees, but has additional user rights that allow them to create or change content and to monitor each student's performance. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE
VMDVeterinary Medicines DirectorateArms Length Body of DefraDefra

WABWales Advisory BoardThe Wales Advisory Board is made up of senior leaders from our member companies. It advises on the Wales strategic plan, supports BITC* Cymrus engagement with government and corporate stakeholders and helps to grow the responsible business movement and our network in Wales. Their priorities are: Advising on BITC's strategy for Wales Supporting engagement with government and corporate stakeholders Growing the responsible business network in Wales * Business in the Community which is the oldest and largest business-led membership organisation dedicated to responsible business. Created by HRH The Prince of Wales to champion responsible business. Source: {WAB|https://www.bitc.org.ukode/361421} accessed 2019-06-14DFE

WAHWorking At HomeDFE
WalWales Office
WAMGWorkforce Agreement Monitoring GroupThe Workforce Agreement Monitoring Group (WAMG) was a social partnership of 11 organisations representing employers, the government and school workforce unions. It was formed in 2003 to monitor implementation of the national agreement. It ended in 2010. The group worked collaboratively on the wider workforce reform agenda with a common purpose of supporting schools in raising standards and tackling workload issues for staff. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04DFE

WEAWorkers Educational AssociationFounded in 1903, the Workers' Educational Association (WEA) is a charity dedicated to bringing high-quality, professional education into the heart of communities. With the support of nearly 3,000 volunteers, 2,000 tutors and over 10,000 members, we deliver friendly, accessible and enjoyable courses for adults from all walks of life. Source: {WEA website|https://www.wea.org.uk/about-us} accessed 2019-02-05DFE
WEPWork Experience Programme1976-1978.DFE
WESWomen's Engineering SocietyThe Women's Engineering Society is a charity and a professional network of women engineers, scientists and technologists offering inspiration, support and professional development. Working in partnership, we support and inspire women to achieve as engineers, scientists and as leaders; we encourage the education of engineering; and we support companies with gender diversity and inclusion. WES - inspiring and supporting diversity and engineering since 1919. Sources: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04 and WES website accessed 2019-03-04DFE

WHWhite HouseBEISUK Vaccines Taskforce
WJECWelsh Joint Education CommitteeWJEC is an examination board, providing qualifications and exam assessment to schools and colleges in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and independent regions. With over 65 years experience in delivering qualifications, WJEC is the largest provider in Wales and a leading provider in England and Northern Ireland. The organisation employs over 360 people and continues to grow. WJEC was established in 1948 as a consortium of local education authorities in Wales. Now a registered independent charity, the organisation is managed by a Board of Directors and Senior Management Team. Sources: The Knowledge accessed 2019-03-04 and WJEC website 2019-03-04DFE

XWHCross WhitehallCivil Service Wide
YAANYoung Apprentice Ambassador NetworkThe Young Apprenticeship Ambassador Network (YAAN) is a group of past and current apprentices that are members of a local YAAN in their region. The core purpose of the YAAN is to grow and expand the apprenticeship programme by engaging with and providing information on apprenticeships to young people through a number of different activities and events, including schools/6th forms and young people in school academic years 11-13. The role of the ambassador is to promote apprenticeships and inspire other young people by describing their direct experience. Source: {Amazing Apprenticeships website|https://yaan.amazingapprenticeships.com/what-is-the-yaan/} accessed 2018-01-18DFE
YCSYouth Cohort StudyA series of longitudinal surveys that contacts a sample of an academic year-group or "cohort" of young people in the spring following completion of education and usually annually until they are aged 19 or 20. The survey looks at young people's education and labour market experience, their training and qualifications and a wide range of other issues, including socio-demographic variables. Source: DfE RS Gateway as at 2011-01-17DFE
YCTYouth Culture TrustDFE
YECYouth Exchange Centre? departmental initiative Added because it is included in The Knowledge abbreviations wiki 2018-11-13DFE
YFIYoung Fathers InitiativeThe Young Fathers Initiative is a registered charity supported by the Department for Education that aims to: -remove barriers that currently stop young father's involvement in family life; -ensure that young fathers are informed and have the skills required to father their children well; -support children's development, by supporting the active involvement of young fathers; -provide professionals with information, advice and support to develop their work with young fathers. The Institute plans to concentrate on the following areas: -The introduction of a school based programme preparation for fatherhood" targeted at year 10 young men as part of their PHSE and citizenship programme. -Targeted support for young fathers in employment / training (but no guarantee of a job).DFE
YJBYouth Justice BoardThe Youth Justice Board for England and Wales (YJB) is an executive NDPB. Board members are appointed by the Secretary of State for Justice. The YJB oversees the youth justice system in England and Wales. Source: {Ministry of Justice website|http://www.justice.gov.uk/about/yjb/} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
YMFYouth Media FundLaunched in 2006 Mediabox enabled young people to create media projects and get their voices heard. Source: Mediabox website as at 2012-05-14DFE
YOFYouth Opportunity Fund2005/unknownDFE
YOPYouth Opportunities Programme1978-1983.DFE
YOTYouth offending teamsThere is a YOT in every local authority in England and Wales. They are made up of representatives from the police, Probation Service, social services, health, education, drugs and alcohol misuse and housing officers. Source: {GOV.UK|https://www.gov.uk/youth-offending-team} accessed 2015-06-11DFE
YPD (departmental organisational unit)Young Peoples DivisionYear(s) active (where known): 2013DFE
YPGYoung Persons GuaranteeDFE
YPLAYoung Peoples Learning AgencyLaunched April 2010. Sponsored by the Department for Education to support the delivery of training and education to all 16-19 year olds in England. From April 1st 2012 the responsibilities of the YPLA have transferred to the Education Funding Agency.DFE
YPMADYoung Persons Matched Admin DataYPMAD covers the attainment of 16-19 year olds (including some information on older ages) in England and also captures information on pupil characteristics. It is a longitudinal dataset which allows students' progress to be tracked. YPMAD is generated by matching several data sources (school census, awarding organisation and individualised learner record data). YPMAD is used to underpin the National Statistics output Level 2 and 3 attainment by young people aged 19, which is used to estimate the skill levels of the overall population at age 19. Unlike the figures in school performance tables, it is not used for accountability purposes so YPMAD allows for a longer and more consistent time-series. Source: Team source 2020-02-24DFE
YREYear round educationDFE
YROYouth Rehabilitation OrderThe Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO) came into effect on 30 November 2009 and will provide judges and magistrates with a choice of 18 rigorous options from which they will be able to create a sentence specifically designed to deal with the individual circumstances of the young offender before them and so help them turn their backs on crime. The YRO will consolidate and enhance existing community sentences to enable courts to sentence in a flexible and tailored way. The YRO provides a range of sentencing options that will punish effectively and rehabilitate young people, including intensive fostering, intensive surveillance and supervision requirements, electronic monitoring, curfews, the required attendance of substance abuse or mental health programmes as well as undertaking tough community work and reparation. This could include apologising to their victim, in order to make visible amends for their crimes.DFE
YSDAYouth Sector Development FundThe Youth Sector Development Fund (YSDF) has been set up to provide a direct response to the commitments in Aiming High for Young People/Aiming High for young people: a ten year strategy for positive activities to build the capacity of third sector organisations. The YSDF will support third sector organisations (TSOs) that can demonstrate effective approaches to engaging and empowering young people, particularly the most disadvantaged. From April 2008, up to 100 million will be available to provide a mixture of large and small grants and expert business support to help these organisations sustain and grow their provision so that more young people can benefit from the activities they offer. Grants totalling 27m have already been awarded through the YSDF to five organisations, Leap Confronting Conflict, Fairbridge, Kids Company, Speaking up and UK Youth who each help and support some of our most disadvantaged young people. DFE
YSSYouth Support ServiceDFE
YSTYouth Sport TrustDFE
YTYouth Training1990/1995.DFE
YTCYouth Treatment CentreDFE
YTSYouth Training Scheme1983/1986. One year scheme. It was introduced in September 1983, and the training period was extended to 2 years in April 1986. The scheme was replaced by Youth Training (YT) in April 1990. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-02-05DFE
YVCYoung Volunteer ChallengePilot scheme ran 2003-05. Through the Young Volunteer Challenge pilot (YVC) a young person will have the opportunity to do some volunteering work after they leave school. The pilot is being run in 9 areas within England until September 2005, and offers opportunities for 820 young people for whom finance is the main barrier to participate in volunteering. This full-time initiative (full-time is defined as more than 30 hours per week) will target 18 and 19 year olds who have completed their programmes of post-16 learning with the support of an Education Maintenance Allowance (EMA), or were eligible for Income Support while undertaking vocational training. The age range will be extended to 21 years for young people with special needs or disabilities. Volunteers will receive a weekly allowance of 45, and an end of experience award of 750 after completing 9 months experience. The pilot will also seek to enhance the personal development of the volunteers in such areas as communication, personal planning, teamwork and leadership skills as well as their commitment to further learning, employment and volunteering. Source: The Knowledge accessed 2019-02-05DFE
ZCTFZero Carbon Task ForceDFE
